choices.text:
in python make a plot that compares two columns in a dataframe.
To compare two columns in a Pandas DataFrame in Python, you can use the `DataFrame.plot()` method to create a scatter plot of the data. Here's an example code snippet that creates a scatter plot comparing two columns in a sample DataFrame called "df":
```python
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

# create the dataframe with some data
data = {
    'A': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
    'B': [0.7, 0.8, 0.9, 1.0, 1.1]
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# split the data into training and testing sets
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(df['A'], df['B'], test_size=0.25, random_state=42)

# create a linear regression model using the training set data
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# predict values on the testing set and plot the results
y_pred = model.predict(X_test)
plt.scatter(df['A'], df['B'])
plt.plot(range(len(y_test)), y_pred[0: len(y_test)], color='red', linewidth=2, label='Predicted Values')
plt.xlabel('Column A')
plt.ylabel('Column B')
plt.title('Comparing Columns in a Pandas DataFrame')
plt.legend()
plt.show()
```
This code will create a scatter plot of the data with one axis representing column "A" and the other axis representing column "B". The red line represents the predicted values from the linear regression model, which is trained on the training set data using the `train_test_split()` function from scikit-learn.
